File.Title: Amygdalonigral Pathway: An Anterograde Study in the Rat With Phaseolus d ' u h Leucoagglutinin (PHA-L)

Introduction.S: The substantia nigra (SN), a mesencephalic nucleus composed of three subregions, the pars compacta, reticulata, and lateralis, plays an important role in the control of movement (Penney and Young, '86).
The major input to the SN originates in the neostriatum and terminates, in a topographically organized fashion, in all three subregions of the nucleus (Szabo, '70; Royce and Laine, '84; Gerfen, '85).
Other areas of the brain project to more discrete parts of the SN.
These nonstriatal inputs include afferents from the globus pallidus, the subthalamic nucleus, the hypothalamus, the raphe nuclei, and the tegmentopedunculopontine nucleus (see Parent, '86).

In addition, several studies have suggested the existence of a projection from the central nucleus of the amygdala (CeN) to the SN in rats (Bunney and Aghajanian, '76; Krettek and Price, '78a; Cassell et al., '86; Wallace et al., '89), cats (Hopkins and Holstege, '78; Krettek and Price, '78a), and monkeys (Price and Amaral, '81).

In view of the role played by the CeN in the control of autonomic function (Kapp et al., '79; Applegate et al., '83), and the association of this nucleus with the limbic system (Sarter and Markowitsch, '85; Price et al., '87), the amygdalonigral pathway could play a critical role in the integration of emotional and motor components of behavior.

This could be of particular importance in pathological situations such as Parkinson's disease, Huntington's chorea, or dystonia, in which stress and emotions are known either to improve or to worsen motor symptoms.

The hypothesis that the CeN projects to the SN is largely based on the presence of silver grains over the SN after injection of tritiated amino acids in the CeN (Hopkins and Holstege, '78; Krettek and Price, '78a; Price and Amaral, '81).

In addition, retrogradely labeled neurons were found in the CeN after injection of retrograde tracers in the lateral, and in some studies the medial, SN (Bunney and Aghajanian, '76; Cassell et al., '86).
These data suggest that a component of the amygdaloid projection to the brainstem terminates in subregions of the SN.

Because of the technical limitations inherent to the methods used, however, these previous studies could not eliminate the possibility that amygdaloid fibers were passing through, rather than terminating within, the SN.

In the present study, we have used the anterograde tracer Phaseolus uulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L; Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84) to label the amygdaloid projection to the SN in an attempt to confirm the presence of terminal fields of amygdaloid neurons in the SN, determine their precise distribution, and identify the location of the cells of origin of this neuronal pathway.
PHA-L was microiontophoretically injected in restricted areas of the CeN and neighboring regions in the rat.
PHA-L-containing fibers were visualized by immunohistochemistry with an antibody against PHA-L (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84).
Their distribution, as well as the presence of terminal-like arborizations and swellings, was examined in the SN and adjacent dopaminergic cell groups with light microscopy.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Forty male Sprague-Dawley rats, 250-350 g, purchased from Ace Animal facility (Boyertown, PA), were used in this study.
Stereotaxic surgery was performed under anesthesia with Chloropent (3.3 ml/kg).
Glass micropipettes with a 20-30 pm-diameter tip were filled with a 0.5% PHA-L solution in 0.1M sodium phosphate buffer containing 0.9 % NaCl pH 7.4.
The injections were made by pulsing a 5kA current (7 seconds on/7 seconds off) through the micropipette with a Midgard current source for 15 to 20 minutes (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84).

The stereotaxic coordinates ranged from 1.9 to 2.3 mm caudal to bregma in the anteriorposterior plane, 4.0 mm lateral to the sagittal suture, and 7.9-8.0 mm ventral to the surface of the skull (Paxinos and Watson, '86).

After a survival time of 7-12 days, the animals were deeply reanesthesized with Chloropent and perfused transcardially with saline for 1-2 minutes, followed by 4% paraformaldehyde in O.1M acetate buffer pH 6.5 for 10 minutes, and by 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.05M borate buffer pH 9.5 for 15 minutes on ice.
The brains were removed and postfixed in the last fixative with 10% sucrose overnight at 4Â°C.
Thirty micron sections were cut on a sliding microtome and collected into small glass vials containing 0.02M potassium phosphate-buffered saline (KPBS).
Every third section was processed for PHA-L immunohistochemistry according to the method of DeVries et al. ('88) modified from Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84).
Sections were rinsed in KPBS (2 x 10 minutes) and preincubated in KPBS containing 0.3% Triton-X and 2% normal rabbit serum for 2-4 hours.
The sections were incubated on a shaking platform at 4OC for 48 hours with an antibody to PHA-L raised in a goat (Vector Laboratories) and diluted 1:2,000 in the preincubation solution.

After incubation in the primary antiserum, the sections were rinsed 2 x 15 minutes in KPBS and processed for the avidin-biotin peroxidase reaction (Hsu et al., '81) with reagents of the Vectastain antigoat ABC Kit from Vector Laboratories and following the manufacturer's instructions.

Briefly, sections were incubated 1 hour in biotinylated rabbit antigoat IgG diluted 1:222 in KPBS with 0.3% Triton-X and 2% normal rabbit serum, rinsed 2 x 10 minutes in KPBS, and incubated 45 minutes in a peroxidase-labeled avidin-biotin solution in KPBS.

The sections were rinsed 2 x 10 minutes, processed through the same procedure again (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84), and rinsed 3 x 10 minutes in KPBS before development of the peroxidase reaction product by using 0.05 % diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride (Polysciences) and 0.003% H,O, in KPBS for 10-15 minutes.
After the reaction, sections were rinsed in cold KPBS (3 x 10 minutes), mounted on gelatin-coated slides, and air dried.

Sections through the injection site were coverslipped without counterstain with Eukitt (Calibrated Instruments, Inc.), and sections through the projection sites were lightly counterstained with thionin to determine the precise location of the labeled processes.

The PHA-L reaction product was intensified in selected sections by dipping the slides in a 0.1% osmium tetroxide (Electron Microscopy Sciences) in distilled water for 1 minute and then dehydrating and coverslipping the section with Eukitt.
Sections adjacent to those processed for immunohistochemistry were stained with thionin or cresyl violet.
Labeled processes were examined by means of brightfield and darkfield microscopy.
Injection sites were drawn with the aid of a projection microscope.
Charting of labeled fibers was done with a drawing tube.
Anatomical areas were identified in Nissl-stained sections according to the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86).

Results.S: RESULTS
Injection sites located within the CeN

The injection sites ( Figs . 1A , B , 4B , B , 11A , D ) were characterized by the presence of a cluster of intensely immunoretive cell bodies embedded in a dense network of labeled neuronal processes .
Ten of the injection sites involved some aspect of the CeN.

TTE.S: One of them, case 35, was a large injection including most subregions of the CeN.
This case will be described in detail followed by two cases that are representative of smaller, nonoverlapping, injections.
The other cases will be described in relation to these.
Large injection into CeN case 35
The injection site for case 35 was mostly contained within the CeN , but extended dorsally in the sublenticular region .
It was primarily located centrally but also extended into the dorsal, lateral , and , caudally , the medial subregions of the CeN ( Figs . 1A , D , 2A , 9C - F ) .
The injection site began approximately 1.8 mm and ended approximately 2.5 mm caudal to bregma (Fig. 9C-F).
At the level of the injection site , labeled fibers were seen in the ipsilateral stria terminalis , a major efferent pathway from the CeN , ventral to the lateral ventricle ( not shown ) .
Other fibers were seen leaving the injection site medially and coursing ventral to the internal capsule ( Fig . 2A , B ) .
A few fibers and bouton - like swellings were present in the dorsomedial hypothalamic area ( Fig . 2B ) .
Rostra1 to the substantia nigra , however , the only prominent terminal field was observed in the lateral hypothalamus ( Figs . 1E , C , 2B - D ) .
Terminal arborizations and varicosities in this area contrasted with the aspect of en passage fibers travelling dorsal to the cerebral peduncle ( Fig . lE , F ) .
Fibers of passage were also seen crossing through the lateral aspect of the cerebral peduncle in a ventrodorsal direction ( Figs .
IF, 2D).

Some of these fibers travelled in a lateromedial direction above the cerebral peduncle and the subthalamic nucleus towards the lateral hypothalamus ; others continued dorsally through the zona incerta ( Figs . lF , 2C , D ) .

Caudal to the lateral hypothalamus , a few scattered fibers with arborizations and bouton - like swellings were observed in the medial SN pars compacta and the lateral ventral tegmental area ( Figs . 2E , F , 3A - D ) .
From these regions , labeled fibers extended above the SN in a dorsolateral orientation ( Fig . 2E - F ) .
Laterally , labeled fibers were detected in the cerebral peduncle and the SN pars reticulata ( Fig . 2E ) .
Some formed bouton-like structures just dorsal to the SN, but many continued to travel dorsally (Fig. 2E).

At the level of the red nucleus , there were fewer labeled fibers in the medial SN pars compacta and the ventral tegmental area and no bouton - like swellings were seen in the more caudal part of these regions ( Fig . 2G ) .

As the SN pars compacta extended laterally , the number of labeled fibers emerging from the cerebral peduncle increased and a dense network of bouton - like structures appeared above and within the lateral SN pars compacta ( Figs . 2F , 3F , G ) .
Terminal arborizations and boutons were also seen , but at a lower density , in SN pars lateralis ( Figs . 2F , 3F , H ) .
These two areas remained labeled with fibers and bouton - like structures through the caudal SN ( Fig . 2G ) .
A large contingent of the fibers emerging from the lateral peduncle did not terminate within the SN , but continued dorsally ( Figs . 2F , G , 3F ) .
These fibers broke into a dense network of terminal - like structures in the lateral retrorubral field , caudal and dorsal to the lateral pars compacta ( Fig . 2H ) .
Numerous labeled fibers continued caudally in a mediolateral orientation but were not followed further in the present study .

Results.S: When the pattern of labeling obtained from smaller injection sites that were restricted to subregions of the CeN was examined , it became apparent that although labeling in the lateral hypothalamus , the ventral tegmental area , and the medial SN pars compacta was present in all cases , only a fraction of the cases showed heavy labeling in the lateral SN .
This difference is illustrated in a comparison of the labeling observed in the SN in cases 22 and 12, which had injection sites of comparable size, but of different location.
Dorsal and central injection into caudal CeN.
case 22

TTE.S: The injection site in case 22 was small and mostly confined to the dorsal and central parts of the rostra1 CeN .
It extended rostrally in the most ventral part of the substriatal region but did not involve the fundus striati (Figs. 4A,B, 5A,B, 9A-C).
Labeled fibers extended medially from the injection site and coursed ventrally to the internal capsule as they entered the ventral amygdalofugal pathway .
Many of these fibers gave rise to bouton - like structures within the lateral hypothalamus , but none were seen in the dorsomedial hypothalamic area ( Fig . 5C ) .
Only a few labeled fibers were observed in the stria terminalis .

More caudally , labeling in case 22 included labeled fibers crossing the lateral cerebral peduncle , and fibers traveling lateromedially above the cerebral peduncle and subthalamic nucleus( Fig . 5C ) .

In the SN , labeling in the medial pars compacta ( Figs . 5D , 6E ) , as well as in the lateral pars compacta , pars lateralis , and retrorubral field ( Figs . 6E - H , 7A - C , 8A , B ) was identical to that described for case 35 ( see for comparison Figs . 2E - H , 3F - Hf .

Results.S: Ventral and medial injection into caudal CeN case 12

TTE.S: The injection site of case 12 was more caudal and mostly involved the ventral part of the medial CeN , extending below the CeN into the intra - amygdaloid division of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( Figs . 4A , B , 5A , B , 9D - G ) .
Labeled fibers extended medially from the injection site , ventral to the internal capsule ( Fig . 5A , B ) .
A few labeled bouton - like structures were present in the dorsomedial hypothalamic area ( Fig . 5C ) and numerous labeled fibers were observed in the stria terminalis .

Although many fibers and bouton - like structures were present in the lateral hypothalamus , no labeled fibers of passage were observed dorsal to the cerebral peduncle and the subthalamic nucleus ( Fig . 5C ) .
Similarly , the labeled fibers crossing the cerebral peduncle were absent in case 12 ( Fig . 5C ) .

Labeled bouton - like structures were Seen in the medial SN pars compacts and ventral tegmental area ( Fig . 4D ) , as well as fibers travelling from these areas in a dorsolateral direction through the mesencephalic reticular formation ( Fig . 5D , 6E ) .
No labeling , however , was observed in the lateral aspect of the cerebral peduncle , the SN pars reticulata , the lateral SN pars compacta , and the SN pars lateralis ( Figs . 6E - G , 7E , F ) .
A few terminal arborizations were observed in the retrorubral field in case 12 ( Figs . 6H , 8D ) , but they were conspicuously fewer than in case 22 ( compare Fig . 8D and B ) .

Results.S: These results show that cases 12 and 22, which differ in the location of the injection site within the central nucleus , can be distinguished on the basis of the presence or absence of labeling in the lateral SN .

In order to identify the area of the CeN which gave rise to the projection to the lateral SN, the cases in which the injection site involved the CeN were grouped according to the presence or absence of this pathway.
Other injections in the CeN showing labeling in the lateral SN cases 16 and 36

TTE.S: In addition to cases 35 and 22, cases 16 and 36 showed dense labeling in lateral SN pars compacta and the retrorubra1 field .
As in cases 35 and 22, labeling was also observed in the SN pars lateralis , and labeled fibers of passage were present in the lateral cerebral peduncle .
Labeling was also present in the medial SN pars compacta and lateral ventral tegmental area .

The injection site in case 16 was relatively small and involved mostly the dorsal portion of the lateral CeN , extending in the sublenticular region and in the amygdalostriatal transition area ( Fig . 9C - E ) .
In case 36, the injection site was larger and included the dorsal and rostral part of the medial CeN .
Labeled cell bodies were also present in the sublenticular area , the globus pallidus , and medially , in the substantia innominata ( Fig . 9C - F ) .
All of the injection sites labeling a projection to the lateral SN involved the dorsal part of the CeN between 1.5 mm and 2.5 mm caudal from bregma (Fig. 9A-F).

In contrast , extensions of the injection site into the substriatal area or the globus pallidus were only observed in isolated cases and do not seem a prerequisite for the presence of the projection to lateral SN .

Results.S: Other injections in the CeN not resulting in labeling in lateral SN cases 17,29,32,38,39

TTE.S: Cases 17,29,32,38,39 along with case 12 did not give rise to any significant labeling in the lateral SN .

The injection site of case 17 was contained within the CeN and involved mostly the rostral and ventral portions of the lateral CeN, extending laterally in the lateral capsular region ( Fig . 9C - E ) .
In case 29, the injection was located in the caudal portion of the lateral CeN and in the amygdalostriatal transition area , but did not involve the lateral amygdaloid nucleus ( Fig . 101 - K ) .
Case 32 had an injection site located primarily in the medial CeN and in the ventral part of lateral CeN ( Figs . 9F , G , 10H ) .

The injection sites in case 38 and 39 were both located in the rostral portion of medial CeN , but 38 was more ventral and lateral than 39, and extended rostrally in the anterior amygdaloid area and the substriatal region ( Fig . 9A , B ) .
In case 39, the injection was located in the medial portion of medial CeN and extended medially into the substantia innominata ( Fig . 9A - D ) .
None of these injection sites included the dorsal part of CeN , nor the sublenticular area , except for a few cells in case 39, and the most caudal portion of dorsal CeN in case 29.
From this series , case 39 was the only one in which a few labeled fibers were observed in the lateral SN , but even in this case , the labeling was much less dense than in cases 16,22,35, and 36.

All cases except case 29, however , contained labeled fibers and bouton - like structures in the lateral hypothalamus , the medial SN pars compacta , and the ventral tegmental area , as well as fibers coursing diagonally in the mesencephalic reticular formation dorsal to the SN .

Results.S: Injections outside the CeN
Injections outside the CeN resulting in labeling in lateral SN: cases 14, 15, 34.
A dense labeling in the lateral SN was also observed in three additional cases ( 14, 15, and 34 ) in which the injection site did not include the CeN per se .
These injection sites were located either dorsal or dorsal and rostral to the CeN , in the area defined as the extended amygdala by Alheid and Heimer ( 88 ) .

TTE.S: In case 15, the injection was dorsal and medial to CeN, and just ventral to the globus pallidus (Fig. 11A,B).
Dense labeling was observed in SN pars lateralis ( Fig . 1lC ) and , to a lesser extent , in lateral and medial SN pars compacta , ventral tegmental area, and retrorubral field ( not shown ) .

The injection site in case 34 was located rostrally to CeN , in the substriatal region and the substantia innominata ( Fig . 11D , E ) , and extended caudally to the level of the CeN , but remained dorsal to this nucleus .

Labeled fibers were abundant in the lateral SN ( both pars compacta and lateralis , Fig . 11F ) and the retrorubral field ( not shown ) , but were very sparse in the medial SN pars compacta and ventral tegmental area .
In case 14, the injection site was entirely rostral to CeN , located in the substriatal region and the anterior amygdaloid area .

Dividing fibers were observed in the lateral SN pars compacta and in the retrorubral field , but the labeling was very sparse in the medial SN pars compacta , the ventral tegmental area , as well as in the SN pars lateralis .

Results.S: Injections outside the CeN not resulting in lateral SN labeling: cases 19, 20, 28, 31, 33.

TTE.S: Five other injection sites were located within the amygdala but did not include the CeN .
In case 19, the injection was ventral and caudal , involving the posterolateral cortical amygdaloid nucleus .
The injections in cases 20 and 33 were located in the lateral part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala , and extended ventrally in the substantia innominata .
In case 28 the injection site involved the lateral and the dorsal tip of the basolateral amygdaloid nuclei .
No labeled fibers were seen in the lateral SN pars compacta nor in the SN pars lateralis in any of these cases , but a sparse labeling was observed in medial SN pars compacta in cases 20 and 28.
A much heavier labeling in medial SN pars compacta , however , was observed after an injection in the intercalated nucleus of the amygdala ( case 31 ) .

Results.S: Cells of origin of the amygdalonigral pathway

In order to confirm that the projection to the lateral SN described in this study originates from neurons of the amygdala rather than from adjacent structures , sections adjacent to those processed for PHA - L immunoreactivity were stained for Nissl , and the cells located in the area corresponding to the PHA - L injection examined at high power with light microscopy .
An example is given in Figure 12 for the injection site in case 35, which gave rise to a dense labeling in the lateral SN pars compacta and SN pars lateralis .
The cells located within the area of the extended amygdala included in the injection site (Fig. 12B) are less densely packed than in CeN (Fig. 12C).
They have the same size and general morphology , however , as those cells located in the center of the CeN ( Fig .
IZC).
Cells of both the CeN and the extended amygdala were easily distinguished from cells in the caudoputamen , which were slightly larger , rounder , and paler ( Fig . 12E ) .
Cells in the extended amygdala were also clearly distinct from the much larger neurons of the adjacent globus pallidus ( Fig . 12F ) .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

Previous studies have suggested that neuronal fibers originating in the CeN reach the medial (Cassell et al., 86) and lateral SN (Bunney and Aghajanian, 76; Krettek and Price, 78a; Cassell et al., 86).

The present results confirm and extend those data by showing evidence of terminal fields of amygdalofugal neurons in discrete areas of the medial and lateral pars compacta and in the pars lateralis of the SN.

In addition, our data suggest that innervation of these subregions of SN originates in different parts of the CeN, with the cell bodies giving rise to the lateral projection located in the dorsal aspect of the CeN and in its rostra1 extension, a part of the extended amygdala (de Olmos et al., 85; Holstege et al., 85; Alheid and Heimer, 88).
Terminals of amygdaloid neurons in the substantia nigra

The existence of a projection from the CeN to the SN has been previously reported after injection of labeled amino acids in the amygdala (Hopkins and Holstege, 78; Krettek and Price, 78a; Price and Amaral, 81).

In these studies, however, silver grains observed in the SN could not be distinguished with absolute certainty from labeled fibers passing through this area on their way to more caudal projection sites (Hopkins and Holstege, 78; Krettek and Price, 78a).
In contrast, it is possible to distinguish en passage fibers and terminal arborizations in experiments using the anterograde tracer PHA-L.

Furthermore, previous electron microscopic studies have confirmed that the swellings and varicosities observed at the light microscopic level in areas of dense axonal arborization of PHA-L-labeled fibers correspond to synaptic boutons characteristic of neuronal terminal fields (Wouterlood and Groenewegen, 85).
Accordingly, the morphological characteristics of the labeled fibers observed in the present study strongly support the assumption that amygdalofugal fibers innervate the substantia nigra.
The pattern of PHA-L labeling also confirmed that the terminal fields of the amygdaloid projection are restricted to defined subregions of the SN.

In all cases with injections in the CeN, the innervation of the medial aspect of the SN pars compacta was very sparse and a similar density of terminals was observed in the adjacent lateral ventral tegmental area.
These sparse terminal fields seemed to extend caudally from the much denser innervation seen in the lateral hypothalamus, and were restricted to the rostral SN and ventral tegmental area.

In contrast, the amygdaloid innervation of the lateral SN pars compacta consisted of a dense plexus of terminal arborizations occupying the full extent of the lateral third of the pars compacta from its rostral to caudal poles.
Part of this plexus originated from fibers crossing through the cerebral peduncle in a ventrodorsal direction and dividing as they reached the ventral border of the pars compacta.
The dorsal aspect of lateral pars compacta received collaterals emerging from the fibers travelling around the lateral pole of pars compacta and above the SN in a lateromedial direction.

Therefore, PHA-L-labeled fibers were distributed to both the dorsal and the ventral tiers of SN pars compacta in this lateral region of SN, but were restricted to the dorsal tier of the nucleus more medially.

The presence of varicosities and boutons in this area strongly suggests that axon terminals originating in the CeN directly innervate dopaminergic neurons which represent the main neuronal cell type in this region (Fallon and Moore, 78 Gerfen et al., 87).

The density of labeled fibers was always less in the pars lateralis than in the lateral pars compacta, and we never observed any terminal field in the SN pars reticulata as previously reported in the cat (Hopkins and Holstege, '78).

This could be related to species differences, to the location of the injection sites in our study, although all parts of the CeN were injected in the present series of experiments, or to the difficulty of distinguishing "en passage fibers" from terminal fields with the labeled amino acids technique.

With the PHA-L method, it was possible to demonstrate that labeling in SN pars reticulata, in the rat, was entirely related to the presence of "en passage" fibers travelling towards the SN pars compacta and lateralis.
Bilateral projections from the CeN to the substantia nigra were reported in the cat (Hopkins and Holstege, '78) and the monkey (Price and Amaral, '81).
No labeled fibers were observed in the side contralateral to the injection in our material.
This may be related to the small size of each injection site, which may have been insufficient to label a weak contralateral projection.
Cells of origin of the nigral projection

Studies based on the use of retrograde tracers have shown that the CeN is by far the primary source of amygdaloid afferents to the SN (Bunney and Aghajanian, '76; Hopkins and Holstege, '78; Cassell et al., '86).

This was confirmed in the present experiments as far as the innervation of the lateral SN is concerned but inputs to the medial pars compacta and ventral tegmental area were observed after injections centered in the intercalated nucleus of the amygdala as well as the CeN.

In some of the previous studies, however, the results suggested that labeled cell bodies could only be observed in the CeN after injections of retrograde tracers in the lateral part of the SN (Bunney and Aghajanian, '76).
It is not surprising that the projection from the CeN to the medial SN pars compacta was not always observed considering the small number of fibers present in this area.

Cassell et al. ('86) considered the possibility that the presence of labeled cell bodies in the CeN after injection of retrograde tracers in the medial SN could be due to injection of fibers of passage.

Our data, however, suggest that the neurons of the CeN terminate in the medial pars compacta and ventral tegmental area and confirm that this projection originates from cells located in most areas of the CeN.
One of the most striking results obtained in this study was the discrete location of the cell bodies projecting to lateral SN.

This is consistent with the results of Cassell et al. ('86), but contrasts with the more extensive distribution of labeled cells in the CeN after injection of retrograde tracers in the lateral SN in other studies (Bunney and Aghajanian, '86).

This apparent discrepancy may be explained by the presence of fibers originating in other parts of the CeN and travelling in a mediolateral and oblique direction in the mesencephalic reticular formation dorsal to the SN.
These fibers could have been included in the injection sites of the retrograde tracers, which can be taken up by damaged fibers of passage and lead to a more widespread labeling within the CeN.

Dorsally situated cells in the CeN that gave rise to the innervation in the lateral SN were not located in an area previously singled out on the basis of its cytoarchitectonic characteristics in the rat (Krettek and Price, '78b; McDonald, '82; Cassell et al., '86).

It has been recently recognized, however, that the dorsal portion of the CeN extends rostrally towards the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (McDonald, '83; Holstege et al., '85; de Olmos et al., '85; Alheid and Heimer, '88).
These two nuclei and the cell bridges located in the sublenticular region dorsal and rostral to the CeN define the "extended amygdala" (Alheid and Heimer, '88).
It is noteworthy that cell bodies lying just above and medial to the rostral CeN were labeled after injections of retrograde tracers in the lateral SN (Cassell et al., '86).

Our observation that injection sites involving these cells, but excluding the CeN, also label fibers in the lateral SN further supports the existence of similarities between cells of the extended amygdala and of the rostrodorsal CeN.
This hypothesis is also consistent with data in the cat (Hopkins and Holstege, '78) showing that the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis projects to the lateral SN.

The absence of labeling in the lateral SN after one injection in the medial amygdaloid nucleus further suggests that it is the lateral, and not the medial division of the extended amygdala which gives rise to this projection.

Whether other regions of the extended amygdala (rostromedial substantia innominata, medial accumbens, medial bed nucleus of the stria terminalis or ventrolateral septum) also contribute inputs to the lateral SN in the rat remains to be established.
Many of the PHA-L-positive fibers innervating the lateral SN appeared to emerge form axons pursuing their course in the reticular formation dorsal to the SN.
This suggests that at least some of the fibers innervating the SN are collaterals of axons projecting to other areas of the brain.
It is unclear, however, which amygdaloid output gives rise to the terminal fields in the SN.

Amygdaloid efferent axons may provide collaterals to the SN on their way to the central gray or to more caudal areas of the brain (Hopkins and Holstege, '78; Cassell et al., '86; Danielson et al., '89).

Injections of retrograde tracers in the dorsal medulla, however, mostly label cells outside the restricted area of the central nucleus giving rise to the nigral innervation (Veening et al., '84; Cassell et al., '86).
The amygdalonigral projection in relation to nigral output neurons
The major output of the SN pars compacta is the dopaminergic projection to the striatum.
This nigrostriatal pathway is topographically organized in a mediolateral fashion (Fallon and Moore, '78; Gerfen et al., '87).

In particular, neurons located in the lateral pars compacta, which, according to our results, are the main target of the amygdalonigral pathway, project to the dorsolateral portion of the striatum (Fallon and Moore, '78).
This area has been shown, in the rat, to receive inputs from premotor and motor cortex (Kelley et al., '82).

Projections from basolateral nucleus of the amygdala, in contrast, mostly avoid this region but innervate the ventromedial aspect of the caudate-putamen (Kelley et al., '82; Russchen and Price, '84; Ragsdale and Graybiel, '88).

Accordingly, the basolateral and central nuclei of the amygdala seem to influence two distinct and complementary regions of the caudate-putamen: the ventromedial caudate-putamen is under the direct influence of the basolateral nucleus whereas the dorsolateral part of the nucleus receives information from the CeN by way of the amygdalonigral and nigrostriatal pathways.
The amygdaloid projection to the A8 region, however, could influence broader areas of the striatum.

This terminal field was dense only in those cases in which fibers were also observed in the lateral SN and was restricted to the lateral portion of the retrorubral field, overlapping partially with the A8 dopaminergic cell group.

Whereas some topographical organization of these neurons exists, dopaminergic cells have been retrogradely labeled in this region after injection of tracer in the dorsal and ventral caudate-putamen as well as the nucleus accumbens in the rat (Deutch et al., '88).

The sparse amygdaloid input to the ventral tegmental area and medial pars compacta could also provide indirect amygdaloid input to the ventral caudate-putamen by way of the more medial nigrostriatal neurons (Domesick, '88).
In addition, this medial projection from the amygdala is in a position to influence dopaminergic inputs to the nucleus accumbens and the prefrontal cortex (Domesick, '88).

The striatum is comprised of two compartments, characterized by different sets of inputs, outputs, and neurochemical markers, the striosomes and the extrastriosomal matrix (Graybiel and Ragsdale, '78; Graybiel, '84).
In the cat, the projection from the basolateral nucleus to the caudateputamen is virtually limited to the striosomes (Ragsdale and Graybiel, '88).
Dopaminergic neurons project to different striatal compartments according to their location both in cats and rats (Jimenez-Castellanos and Graybiel, '87; Gerfen et al., '87).
Neurons of the ventral tegmental area and of the A8 cell group project to the extrastriosomal matrix.

Within the SN pars compacta of the rat, the dorsally located neurons project to the extrastriosomal matrix of the caudateputamen whereas the more ventral neurons, which are characterized by the absence of staining for calbindin 28K, project to the striosomes (Gerfen et al., '87).

The distribution of these ventral calbindin-negative neurons, however, is restricted to the medial and midsections of the pars compacts, and does not extend into the lateral portion which receives the amygdaloid input (Gerfen et al., '85).

According to these data, the dopaminergic neurons contacted by neurons of the CeN project primarily to the extrastriosomal matrix, suggesting that the direct inputs from the basolatera1 and indirect inputs from the central nuclei could innervate distinct and complementary compartments, as well as subregions of the striatum.

In addition to its projection to the striatum, the SN pars compacta also sends efferents to a number of limbic regions including the CeN in rats and cats (Fallon et al., '78; Meibach and Katzman, '88; Seroogy et al., '89).

There is a striking similarity between the distribution of amygdaloid fibers in the SN pars compacta and the location of nigral neurons projecting to the amygdala, suggesting that these pathways are part of a regulatory loop (Veening et al., '84).
In addition, areas of the ventral tegmental area and of the retrorubral field receiving amygdaloid inputs also project to the CeN (Deutch, '88; Domesick, '88).
Such organization appears common to a number of projections from the CeN.
In fact, areas of the lower brainstem which are innervated by the amygdala also project back to this nucleus (Ricardo and Koh, '78; Saper and Loewy, '80; Veening et al., '84).
Functional considerations

The central nucleus is singled out among other amygdaloid nuclei by its projections to the lower brainstem (Hopkins, '75; Hopkins and Holstege, '78; Krettek and Price, '78a; Hopkins et al., '81; Kawai et al., '82; Van der Kooy et al., '84; Veening et al., '84; Wallace et al., '89).

Neurons projecting to the cardiovascular regulatory centers of the dorsal medulla could mediate a direct action of the CeN in autonomic regulation (Hopkins and Holstege, '78; Van der Kooy et al., '84; Veening et al., '84; Danielsen et al., '89).

In addition to cardiovascular and respiratory effects (Kapp et al., '79), low-intensity stimulations of the CeN elicit somatomotor responses including an arrest of motor behavior and, in the rabbit, movements of the mouth and tongue (Applegate et al., '83).
At higher intensity of stimulation (Applegate et al., '831, escape behavior such as running and leg thumps can be observed.
The projection from the CeN to the SN could be involved in its influence on motor behavior.

Neurons of the SN which project directly to areas involved in the control of movement are located mostly in the pars reticulata and, to a lesser extend, in the pars lateralis of the SN (Beckstead et al., '81; Parent, '86; Harting et al., '88).
According to our data, only the pars compacta and lateralis, but not the pars reticulata, receive amygdaloid inputs in the rat.
This suggests that the influence of the CeN on motor behavior may be either mediated through efferents of the pars lateralis, or involve the striatum, by way of the nigrostriatal pathway.

Alternatively, it is conceivable that the amygdaloid neurons alter the dendritic release of dopamine in the SN, which can in turn affect the output neurons from the pars reticulata (Cheramy et al., '81).
The CeN and extended amygdala receive inputs from autonomic brainstem areas as well as forebrain limbic regions.
Therefore, through their connections with the SN, they have the potential to link the limbic and autonomic systems with the extrapyramidal system.

This key position may be of critical importance to explain the impact of emotions and stress on motor function, in particular in patients with disturbance of the extrapyramidal system such as Parkinson's disease, Huntington's chorea, or dystonia.
